text: Hi, Neil from BBC Learning English here.
Did you know that we are now offering a new weekly extra episode of 6 Minute English,
exclusively on our website?
So go to BBCLearningEnglish.com to find your favourite presenters on your favourite programme.
The extra episodes are only available on our website, BBCLearningEnglish.com.
See you there.
This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I’m Georgina.
speaker: Georgina

text: When it comes to sport, there’s something for everyone. Do you play a sport, Georgina?
speaker: Neil

text: Do you play as sport Georgina?
I used to play in a netball team years ago. Now I go jogging and I enjoy swimming too.
speaker: Georgina

text: Now I go jogging and I enjoy swimming too.
Yes, I go jogging sometimes and I play football, although I’m no Ronaldo!
speaker: Neil

text: But some sports, the so-called full-contact sports like rugby, American football and boxing,
are much more dangerous.
Now the truth about the long-term effects on players who make a career
taking heavy tackles or punches to the head is being slowly revealed.
And the issue of safety and sport was back in the news again recently
when Danish footballer Christian Erickson collapsed on the pitch
during the 2020 European Football Championship.
At the centre of the debate, I'll worry about possible brain damage
and dementia caused by concussion.
That's a type of traumatic brain injury caused by a bump or blow to the head
and the topic of this programme.
Boxing, of course, is one of the most dangerous sports.
And so my quiz question is about a famous boxer.
Born in 1949, this boxer has remained mentally and physically fit
despite years of punishment in the boxing ring.
But who am I talking about?
Is he A. Muhammad Ali, B. George Foreman or C. Mike Tyson?
I'm not a big boxing fan now, but I'll say B. George Foreman.
Okay, Georgina, we'll find out the answer to that question later in the programme.
So far, we’ve been talking about heavy full-contact sports like boxing, but the truth is that any sportsperson can get concussed.
speaker: Georgina

text: But the truth is that any sportsperson can get concussed.
In 2018, hockey player and Olympic gold medalist Nikola White
In 2018 hockey player and Olympic gold medallist, Nicola White was involved in a heavy collision with another player during a warm-up match.
speaker: Neil

text: Here's Nikola telling her story to Paul Connelly,
a presenter of the BBC World Service programme The Inquiry.
I started suffering headaches, nausea,
light sensitivity, noise sensitivity.
My balance was off. I just felt terrible.
I always used to describe it like I was in an Alice in Wonderland.
I just felt in such a warped world.
It just felt relentless and it never stopped.
Three years on from that moment of impact,
Nikola is still picking up the pieces.
Despite seeking advice and treatment from specialists in the field of Hed trauma,
many of her symptoms persist.
After the collision, Nikola's balance was off.
When something is off, it's worse than usual.
And off can also mean ‘bad’, as in ‘this milk smells awful – it’s gone off!’
speaker: off off

text: Nikola felt terrible and her world was warped, strange and unpleasant.
In fact, three years after the accident, she was still picking up the pieces - trying to return to normality after a crisis or collapse.
speaker: picking up the pieces -

text: trying to return to normality after a crisis or collapse.
Concussion is a problem in many sports,
Concussion is a problem in many sports - even those like hockey or athletics that are not considered ‘full contact’.
speaker: Neil

text: But the dangers involved with boxing are far greater.
But the dangers involved with boxing are far greater. In fact, it’s one of the few sports that has concussion written into the rules.
speaker: Georgina

text: Yes, that’s right. When a boxer is knocked down, he has ten seconds to stand up and get his senses together – if he can’t, there’s a good chance he’s concussed.
speaker: Neil

text: and get his senses together.
If he can't, there's a good chance he's concussed.
Tristixson is a former boxer-turned sports writer.
Here he is speaking to BBC World Service programme The Inquiry
about concussion in boxing.
See if you can spot the answer to the quiz question near last earlier.
When you look back through history and you see that Henry Armstrong, Sugar Ray,
Robinson, Muhammad Ali, Joe Lewis all suffered with neurological problems as they got older.
But what we also need to find out is why can you have a fight like George Foreman,
who's now in his 70s and has bright as a button after too long hard careers?
Why do some people seem to have a reserve that has kept them safe later in life?
Tristix mentions some famous boxers who suffered neurological problems in later life
and another boxer who's still as bright as a button.
An expression used to describe someone who's happy, cheerful, intelligent and full of energy.
It seems that some people have a reserve – a supply of energy they keep stored up for use in the future, when it’s needed.
speaker: reserve

text: Okay, Georgina, let's get back to my quiz question and I'm pretty sure you know the answer now.
Yes, I think so.
Yes, I think so. Neil asked me which famous boxer, born in 1949, was still mentally alert despite many years of fighting. I guessed it was b) George Foreman.
speaker: Georgina

text: I guess it was B, George Foreman.
Good listening, Georgina!
speaker: Neil

text: Thanks, Neil - looks like I’m as bright as a button today!
speaker: bright as a button

text: Let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme about concussion – atraumatic brain injury caused by a knock to the head.
speaker: concussion

text: a traumatic brain injury caused by a knock to the head.
When something is off, it’s bad or worse than usual.
speaker: off

text: The adjective warped means strange and unpleasant.
speaker: warped

text: To pick up the pieces means to try to return to the way things were before a crisis or collapse.
A reserve is a supply of something that you kept back until it’s needed.
speaker: reserve

text: And finally, someone who’s as bright as a button is very happy and cheerful, intelligent, and full of energy!
speaker: bright as a button

text: Sounds like our six minute English listeners to me.
That's all for our investigation into concussion in sport,
That’s all for our investigation into concussion in sport, but if you’d like to find out more about the subject you can listen again to the whole programme on the BBC World Service website.
speaker: Georgina

text: And if you want to grow your brain power, not get linguistically concussed,
why not join us again soon for more topical discussion and useful vocabulary here at six minute English from BBC Learning English?
Bye for now.
Bye!
speaker: Georgina
